I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
program loan, and (ii) a proposed project grant, both to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
(Lao PDR) for the Secondary Education Sector Development Program.1 
 
2. 
The  program  loan  will  support  key  policy  reform  actions  focused  on  strengthening  the 
secondary  education  subsector  (SES) 2 throughout  the  Lao  PDR,  and  the  project  grant  will 
finance investments that directly link to, and support delivery of, those policy actions and ensure 
they  are  effectively  put  into  operation.  Complementary  program  and  project  components  will 
collectively  address  key  priorities  related  to  equitable  access,  quality  and  relevance,  and 
subsector  management  in  the  SES.  The  program  will  principally  be  national  in  scope,  with 
access-related project investments targeted to selected disadvantaged and underserved areas.3  
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The Government of the Lao PDR ascribes a high priority to education as a prerequisite 
for  sustained  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction. 4  Government  and  international 
development  partner  (IDP)  efforts  have  focused  on  the  primary  level  (grades  1–5),  and 
significant progress has been made. Gains have also been made in the SES, with the transition 
to a 7-year system marking a key milestone.5 At the same time, key gaps in access, quality and 
relevance, and subsector management undermine the contributions made by the SES and the 
entire  education  system  to  modernization,  equity  and  inclusive  growth,  poverty  reduction,  and 
broader socioeconomic development in the Lao PDR. 
 
4. 
Access.  As  primary  education  has  expanded,  the  SES  has  become  a  key  bottleneck. 
From  SY2006/07  to  SY2009/10,  the  lower  secondary  education  (LSE)  gross  enrolment  ratio 
(GER) rose from 53.3% to 60.2%, with the upper secondary education (USE) GER stagnant at 
34.0%.6 Aggregate  figures  conceal  large  socioeconomic  and  geographic  gaps.7 Particularly  in 
poor,  rural,  and  largely  ethnic  group  areas,  enrolment  rates  decline  steadily  and  gender  gaps 
widen  at  higher  grades.  Expanding  access  requires  policies  and  investments  to  address  an 
array of demand-side issues (e.g., financial and opportunity costs, language and other cultural 
factors, and disabilities) and supply-side factors (e.g., weak school network coverage of remote 
areas, and inadequate financial and human resources), as well as quality issues. 
 
5. 
Quality.  Low  SES  enrolment  and  high rates  of  repetition  and  especially  dropout  partly 
reflect quality gaps.8 Particularly for LSE, rapid rises in the number of primary school graduates

Priorities include bolstering (i) systems and institutions providing pre- and in-service training and 
support  to  SES  teachers;9 (ii)  mechanisms  for  teacher  deployment  to  poor,  rural,  and  largely 
ethnic  group  areas  (particularly  in  subjects  such  as  science  and  math);  and  (iii)  investment  in 
facilities and teaching and learning materials (including textbooks and laboratory facilities). 
 
Subsector management.  Interlinked with access and quality issues, gaps  in subsector 
6. 
management undermine learning outcomes and the internal and external efficiency of the SES. 
Low investment poses an overarching issue for the education sector, and the SES is particularly 
underresourced,  with 
IDP  providing 
comprehensive support.10 Financing gaps compound other urgent SES management challenges: 
(i) institutional capacity, including the need for further rationalization alongside decentralization; 
(ii)  human  resources  and technical  and  managerial  capacities;  (iii)  planning  and  budgeting,  as 
well as management information systems; (iv) assessment of teachers and of student learning 
outcomes, and broader quality control; and (v) enhanced mobilization of private sector actors. 
 
7. 
Sector  development  program  approach.  The  Lao  PDR’s  Education  Sector 
Development  Framework  (ESDF)  provides  (i)  a  plan  with  which  to  operationalize  the  National 
Education System Reform Strategy 2006–2015, and (ii) a unified framework for government and 
IDP  efforts.  Dialogue  toward  ADB’s  next  country  partnership  strategy  for  the  Lao  PDR  has 
identified education as a core sector, and the government has called on ADB to maintain its role 
as the lead IDP supporting the SES. The program will build on, consolidate, and advance key 
SES  reforms  catalyzed  with  support  under  the  ongoing  Basic  Education  Sector  Development 
Program  (BESDP),  which  demonstrated  the  efficacy  of  the  sector  development  program 
modality.11 In particular, the program will seamlessly dovetail with BESDP support for curriculum 
reform,  assisting  the  MOE  to  complete  the  introduction  of  the  new  4-year  LSE  curriculum  by 
SY2013/14  and  in  all  three  USE  grades  by  SY2016/17.  Comprehensive  program  and  project 
support  will  also  build  on  lessons,  models,  and  capacities  built  under  the  BESDP  to  advance 
progress  in  the  SES  under  all  three  ESDF  pillars:  (i)  assuring  equitable  access,  (ii)  improving 
quality and relevance, and (iii) strengthening sector governance and performance management.

C. 

Outputs 

9. 
Directly aligned with the Lao PDR’s ongoing SES reform agenda and the ESDF’s three 
pillars, the program’s outputs will be (i) expanded access to secondary education, (ii) improved 
delivery of new SES curricula, and (iii) strengthened SES management. 
 

1. 

Program Outputs 

Key  policy  actions  supported  under  the  program  are  outlined  in  paras.  11–17,  with

a. 

Expanded Access to Secondary Education 

 
11. 
Stipends  for  disadvantaged  students. The MOE has put a high priority on launching 
and  expanding  needs-based  LSE  and  USE  stipends.13 The  program  and  project  will  support 
development and demonstration of modalities to ensure efficacy and targeting to disadvantaged 
students. The policy matrix includes sequenced policy actions for development and approval of 
beneficiary  selection  criteria  and  interim  implementation  guidelines  (including  targets  for  girls 
and  ethnic  students)  for  MOE-administered  stipends  at  all  post-primary  levels,  followed  by 
resourcing and launch of an expanded SES stipend program for disadvantaged students. 
 
12. 
Dormitories to enhance equitable access. The MOE recognizes dormitories as a key 
instrument for addressing constraints on access, particularly for girls and ethnic group children 
in  remote  villages  located  far  from  secondary  schools.  At  the  same  time,  despite  increasing 
investments,  there  is  no  concrete  policy  for  dormitories  in  the  SES.  Complemented  by 
interventions under the project component, the program will support the MOE’s completion of a 
review  of  existing  dormitories  and  their  impact  on  equitable  access  in  the  SES,  followed  by 
adoption of a related policy on, and guidelines for, dormitories in the subsector. 
 

b. 

Improved Delivery of New Secondary Education Subsector Curricula 

 
13. 
Preservice teacher training, recruitment, deployment, and utilization planning. The 
program (and complementary project support) will help further operationalize existing policies14 
via  a  series  of  policy  actions  aimed  at  (i)  MOE  approval  of  revised  national  curricula  for 
preservice teacher training for LSE and then USE, along with minimum quality standards for all 
13  teacher  training  institutions (TTIs);15 (ii)  conduct  and  evaluation  by  MOE  of  a  pilot  test  of  a 
teacher placement scheme to attract TTI graduates to teach in remote areas; and (iii) approval 
by  MOE of guidelines for use by provincial education services, district education bureaus, and 
institutions concerned with developing annual teacher recruitment and utilization plans. 
 
Improving  in-service  teacher  performance.  Given  the  importance  of  monitoring  and 
14. 
improving  teacher  performance  to  improving  quality  and  advancing  pupil-centered  active 
learning,  the  program  will  support  the  MOE’s  development  and  approval  of  guidelines  and 
adoption of an operational manual for teacher performance monitoring and evaluation (M&E). 
 
15. 
Secondary  education  subsector  curriculum  reform.  As noted in paras. 5 and 7, the 
introduction of an improved curriculum and related materials for the 7-year SES is a core thrust

c. 

Strengthened Secondary Education Subsector Management 

 
Enhanced  resourcing  and  planning  for  education.  The  Lao  PDR  Education  Law, 
16. 
ESDF,  and  other  policy  documents  commit  to  increased  education  sector  investment.  The 
ESDF targets increased and better-managed nonsalary recurrent costs and the introduction of 
block grants as key thrusts. The program will directly support these thrusts, as well as measures 
such  as  school  network  mapping,  which  will  be  essential  to  ensure  that  investments  in  new 
school construction align with the need to efficiently and equitably expand access. Supported by 
project interventions, a series of policy actions aim at achieving (i) the 18% share of education 
in the total budget required by the Education Law; (ii) an increased share of nonsalary recurrent 
expenditures  within  the  MOE’s  total  budget;  (iii)  development  and  approval  of  a  policy  for 
introducing block grants to cover recurrent costs at all levels within the MOE system, supported 
by  a  block  grant  management  manual,  and  subsequent  allocation  and  release  of  block  grants 
for LSE schools in all 30 districts classified as poorest and educationally disadvantaged (para. 
19);  and  (iv)  MOE  completion  of  nationwide  SES  school  network  mapping  and  issuance  of  a 
decree on its use to guide planning for future capital investment.
